This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Buffalo Rock, Birmingham, AL is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard (called Process Safety Management or PSM) and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (called Risk Management Program or RM Program) to deal with the risks involved in the storage, handling, and processing of highly hazardous materials such as ammonia. In this way, we promote overall plant and worker safety.

Our PSM/RM programs enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of highly hazardous materials as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, the PSM/RM programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Our PSM/RM programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.



Our PSM/RM programs contain the following major elements:



?     General Company Policy

?     Employee Participation

?     Process Safety Information

?     Process Hazard Analysis

?     Standard Operating Procedures

?     Training

?     Contractor Qualifications

?     Pre Startup Safety Review

?     Mechanical Integrity Program

?     Hot Work Permit

?     Management of Change

?     Incident Investigation

?     Emergency Planning and Response

?     Compliance Audits

?     Trade Secrets

?     Management System

?     Hazard Assessment

?     Five Year Accident History

?     Preparing a Risk Management Plan (RMP)



The Corporate Director of Safety & Compliance is the program coordinator with overall responsibility to ensure that program goals and objectives are met and appropriate resources are available. The Corporate Director of Safety & Compliance will review and update the program as neces

sary. Copies of the written program may be reviewed through employee communications processes, safety training/audits, and system audits.



If you feel that any improvements can be made to the PSM/RM programs, please contact the Corporate Director of Safety & Compliance. We encourage all suggestions because we are committed to the success of our 



PSM/RM programs. We strive for a comprehensive, integrated prevention system which obtains clear understanding, safe behavior, and involvement in the program from every level of the facility and the public.



Buffalo Rock in Birmingham, Alabama processes and bottles beverages for the soft drink industry. The Ammonia Refrigeration system is used in the production process for removing heat from the process through plate and frame heat exchangers. There are no evaporators in the refrigeration system.



The Ammonia Refrigeration system at Buffalo Rock in Birmingham, Alabama consists of 16 piston compressors manufactured by Vilter with HP ranging from 75 to 150. The compressors are located in 4 mechanical rooms feeding a common header (HSD) with a common suction (HSS).  There is a master accumulator on the suction side of the system to prevent the possibility of carry over.



There are 3 evaporative condensers external to the building elevated at the 2nd floor mezzanine level providing heat removal for the compressed NH3 (v). At this point there is a high pressure receiver tank to act as a buffer for the NH3 (l) entering the HPL common header feeding the heat exchangers via surge drums.



On the process side of the system there are 5 plate and frame heat exchangers, 2 falling film heat exchangers and one shell & tube heat exchanger, all being fed by surge drums with level control. All surge drums have dual SRV's and are connected to relief headers exiting through roof penetrations (roof vents are elevated to 15 ft above roof line with weather caps). There are 2 Viking positive displacement pumps used to circulate NH3 (l)

implementing the PSM/RMP. This is the first time for the company to implement the PSM/RMP since the facility is just now starting the program due to crossing the threshold inventory limit for ammonia. Implementation of the PSM/RMP programs will of itself be both a new standard for the company as well as a continuous improvement tool.
